Message.Title: AMZN sells Distribution Center In AZ For $90M
Message.Msg: "According to Cushman & Wakefield of Arizona Inc. on Tuesday, which brokered the agreement that a Denver-based private real estate investment trust paid $ 90.28 million in cash previous week to get the enormous Amazon..." Why is AMZN selling one of their biggest distributions centers when they are supposedly in expansion mode? http://www.bigticks.com/china-www-stocks/2012/dang-news-amazon-nasdaqamzn-sell-distribution-center-for-90m-amzn-ebay/

Topic.Title: AMZN sells Distribution Center In AZ For $90M

Message.Msg: They aren't selling - it's one of their lessors selling to another. AMZN leases most of their fulfillment centers, those assets you see in the balance sheet are not the fulfillment centers, they're faster depreciating - things like servers, software, etc.

Topic.Title: AMZN sells Distribution Center In AZ For $90M

Message.Msg: Thanks. I thought that AMZN actually owned the land on which they built their distribution centers. Kind of strange that they are spending hundreds on millions to build these centers without buying the land.
Def put buyers. I don't remember prom well, but I think it was more fun than this. Percentage wise, given my age and income, similar re cost.

Topic.Title: AMZN sells Distribution Center In AZ For $90M

Message.Msg: They can not afford to buy the land. Unlike GOOG, which owns server farms, AMZN only leases their distribution centers. It makes the balance sheet look better, but in reality, their liabilities are a whole lot worse. Capital leases as far as the eye can see. All part of the ponzi scheme.

Message.Title: Cramer AAPL to 11K per shr.
Message.Msg: That's right if Jim Cramer can even mention AAPL and Amzn in the same breath then we must assume that if APPL were to get the same valuation that AMZN has then AAPL would be at 11k per share or higher. How he can accept the Bezos line about increasing profits in the future while margins shrink, fullfilment costs going up Profit decline 96% from last yrs Q and they admit that they lose money on every Kindle Fire they sell only show how crazy investing has become .Where up is down and down is up

"With patience, we always win and significantly." Except when you pick the wrong stock (Amazon has nothing to do with a coffee stock) to short. In that case you will always lose, and significantly. You will go away to "refocus" and just never show up here again. And you will have left much poorer than you arrived. The pattern is called "easy come, easy go". Or "the silencing (or quieting) of the paid momo short shill".
